Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: A Sustainable Open Source Software Pipeline for Patient Specific Blood Flow Simulation and Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The SimVascular package is a crucial research tool for cardiovascular modeling and simulation, and has contributed to numerous advances in personalized medicine, surgical planning and medical device design. SimVascular is currently the only comprehensive software package that provides a complete pipeline from medical image data segmentation to patient specific blood flow simulation and analysis. This software now forms the backbone in cardiovascular simulation research in a small but active group of domestic and international academic labs. However, since its original release there have been several critical barriers preventing wider adoption by new users, application to large-scale research studies, and educational access. These include 1) the cost and complications associated with embedded commercial components, 2) the need for more efficient geometric model construction tools, 3) lack of sustainable architecture and infrastructure, and 4) a lack of organized maintenance.

This project is addressing the above roadblocks through the following aims: 1) create a sustainable and modular open source SimVascular 2.0 project housed at Stanford Simbios? simtk.org, with documentation, benchmarking and test suites, 2) provide alternatives to all commercial components in the first truly open source release of SimVascular, 3) improve the image segmentation methods and efficiency of model construction to enable high-throughput studies, and 4) enhance functionality by merging state of the art research in optimization, flow analysis, and multiscale modeling. The project leverages existing resources and infrastructure at simtk.org, and builds upon the significant previous investment that enabled the initial open source release of SimVascular. Access is further enhanced by cross-linking with the NIH funded Vascular Model Repository. This project will increase the user base and build a sustainable software platform supported by an active open source community. Releasing the first fully open source version of SimVascular will enable greater advances in cardiovascular medicine, provide open access to state of the art simulation tools for educational purposes, and facilitate training of young investigators. These efforts will also further promote diversity and attract students to science and engineering by leveraging this software to enable high school field trips to the UCSD StarCAVE to view simulation data using virtual reality.

Institution.Name: University of California-Berkeley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

This project addressed the unmet need for the continued maintenance and development of SimVascular—an open source software for patient-specific blood flow simulation and analysis. SimVascular was partially open sourced through the Simbios center at Stanford in 2007. The software was subsequently used for cardiovascular simulation research in a small but active group of academic labs. However, broader adoption and maintenance were hindered by a number of factors including the cost and complications associated with commercial components, the need for more efficient model construction, and lack of sustainable software architecture and organized maintenance. This project aimed to launch a new sustainable open source project with a growing user base and modular architecture, provide open source alternatives for all embedded commercial components, improve the model construction process, and merge recent modeling methods to extend the functionality of SimVascular. 

This project realized an extensive overhaul of the SimVascular software, which improved its functionality, maintainability and end-user adoption. SimVascular provides a modeling pipeline that involves (1) segmentation of vascular anatomy from medical image data, (2) construction of a computer model from the segmentation(s), (3) volumetric meshing of the computer model to generate a computational domain, and (4) solution of partial differential equations on the computational domain to model blood flow or tissue dynamics. Steps 2-4 originally required commercial (licensed) components and initial efforts were focused on replacing these commercial components with open-source alternatives. Namely, meshing capabilities were developed by integrating existing open-source tools with custom code to provide a range of meshing features. Solid modeling capabilities were maintained by replacing commercial components with custom code for core functionality, as well as integration with the OpenCascade package for additional open-source solid modeling support. An in-house linear solver, svLS, was integrated and included preconditioning to overcome numerical challenges inherent to the boundary conditions required in cardiovascular simulations. These efforts enabled us to remove reliance on all commercial components and make the complete SimVascular pipeline freely available for the first time. 

A number of additional capabilities were included in the course of the project including the addition of 3D image segmentation methods, improved fluid structure interaction modeling, and the ability to access core SimVascular functionality through Python scripting. A milestone of the project was the development of a new graphical user interface (GUI), aimed to improve model construction and user experience, and concomitant changes to the software architecture. Another major focus of this project related to software engineering to improve maintainability of the code. This included development of the build system to manage the extensive dependencies required for the SimVascular pipeline/GUI. The new build process enabled binary installers for major operating systems (MacOS, Windows, Linux) for users, and can use prebuilt dependencies to improve the build process for developers. 

Broader Impacts

Improvements in medical imaging and computational modeling have enabled recent growth in image-based cardiovascular modeling. This progress is highlighted by the recent FDA approval and clinical adoption of image-based modeling for the evaluation of coronary artery disease. SimVascular provides an open-source suite of tools to support similar hemodynamics research for improved diagnosis and treatment planning applications. 

To improve access and education on the software, a new project website www.simvascular.org was developed to provide user/developer guides, case studies and other relevant information related to SimVascular. This site also contains links to binary installations of SimVascular, which are hosted by SimTK.org (https://simtk.org/projects/simvascular), and links to the project source code repositories, which are hosted on GitHub (https://github.com/SimVascular/). A user forum was established through SimTK and feature requests were established through GitHub. We hosted new-user workshops at major biomedical engineering conferences including the 2015 and 2017 Summer Biomechanics, Bioengineering, and Biotransport Conferences and the 2018 World Congress of Biomechanics. Based on usage statistics from SimTK, the SimVascular software has to date been downloaded by around 3000 users from around the world. Furthermore, the SimVascular software developed in this project has also been utilized in courses at several universities. 

This project supported the professional development of doctoral and postdoctoral researchers, including training in biomedical research, software development, project collaboration, and technical communication. This training has been influential to their professional progress and members of the team have continued work in the field of cardiovascular modeling, including in both academia and industry. 

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2019
Modified by: Shawn C Shadden
